Award.AwardTitle: Fundamental Aspects of M-theory and Superspace
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports the research of Professors Katrin Becker and Melanie Becker at Texas A&M University.

One of the biggest challenges in fundamental physics is to develop a unified description of physical phenomena at very large and very small distances. For large distances we use general relativity, and for small distances we use quantum theory. One of the most successful candidates for unifying these two descriptions is string theory, and in particular its most recent generalization into what is called M-theory. After almost twenty years since the discovery of M-theory, we have learned a great deal about this enigmatic theory. However, there are still countless questions about M-theory that are waiting to be answered. As part of their research, Professors K. Becker and M. Becker will explore the formulation, theory, and phenomenology of M-theory. This work advances the national interest by promoting the progress of science at the most fundamental level: the discovery and understanding of the elementary building blocks of matter and of the universe at astronomical scales. The project is also envisioned to have significant broader impacts. Professors K. Becker and M. Becker will involve graduate students and postdoctoral fellows in their research, and thus provide critical training to junior physicists working in this field.

More technically, in their research Professors K. Becker and M. Becker will explore the existence of quantum theories that capture the symmetries of M-theory, its higher-order corrections, and their impact on spacetime geometry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award was used to support one post-doctoral researcher for two years in the Theory Group of the Mitchell Institute at Texas A+M University for research on foundational questions regarding the formulation, theory, and phenomenology of M-theory. Recently-developed technology by groups at Texas A+M and their collaborators was applied to the construction of quantum theories that capture the defining symmetries of this mysterious theory, the study of its higher-order corrections and their impact on the geometry and phenomenology in non-flat backgrounds.

The most significant result was the construction of the action of M-theory with manifest four-dimensional supersymmetry up to first order in the gravitino superfields and to all order in the remaining fields. This is an important step towards finding this action to all orders in all the fields.

Intellectual merit

For the first time since the discovery on M-theory, it appears to be possible to construct quantizable models extending those of string theory to realize (part of) the U-duality symmetry that is the hallmark of M-theory. If the full symmetry can be achieved, the resulting theory would be a strong (if not unique) candidate for the fundamental formulation of M-theory.This approach relies on target space methods which benefit greatly from the superspace actions constructed in the research work supported by this grant. Independently, these have the benefit of representing the low-energy physics of M-theory in what has been shown to be a powerful framework for the calculation of quantum corrections important for model building.


Broader impact

The proposed research is at the frontier of modern high energy physics and has the potential of opening new avenues in the study of the fundamental aspects of quantum gravity and string theory. It also holds the potential for boosting the interfaces between string theory and other areas of physics, such as condensed matter physics, as well as mathematics. Moreover, our work was published in well known journals that are accessible to the general public.
